ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a greater ability to speak Spanish and engage with the language.

In this class, I learned more than just Spanish.  I was. able to understand advanced topics in culture and history. The class exposed me to many of the sociopolitical issues in hispanic countries, especially those of indigenous people.
I expanded my conversational skills, as well as learned to use my Spanish to discuss difficult and serious topics, such as colonization.

I absolutely loved this course and the opportunity it gave me to study subjects I have not dived into before. Between learning about the feminist side of the witch movement, studying protest art, and diving into indigenous cultures, this course enabled me to both immerse myself in the Spanish language while gaining insight into so many cultural components I otherwise would not have known.
I learned a lot about issues of representation and misrepresentation
Increased fluency and ease speaking spanish in conversational settings. More knowledge and insight into culture (indigeneity, fake news, witches!).
I developed my conversational skills in Spanish. Each class was discussion based and encouraged participation so that I felt like I was constantly practicing my speaking skills.
I practiced speaking Spanish more, and learned a lot about marginalized communities and how they use modes of art to communicate to the public and gain platforms.
I practiced my Spanish and learned about the core topics of the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Tordin does a great job at creating in class assignments for the class to interact with one another. I learned a lot through the insights of my classmates. However, I wish we talked more to get conversation flowing just about simple things, so conversation becomes more second hand.

Giseli did an excellent job facilitating the conversation and giving us assignments to prepare us for the discussions in class. I also found the asynchronous days helpful for developing my writing skills.

I thought that this course was super strong regarding its focus on class discussions in Spanish and in-depth writing assignments. I loved having the opportunity to also engage with Spanish media (movies, podcasts, and short films) which propelled my understanding of the language. In terms of weaknesses, there are none that stand out!
I love learning about indigenous women but didnt love really only working with jamboards the whole time.

Strengths were that it was a fun class to be in and the content was fairly different throughout the semester. Weaknesses were that many of our readings still seemed at a higher level than Spanish 140, if we could have gone through the readings again in class, that would have been helpful.
Sometimes there was a lot of busy work where we would be doing work when we probably did not have to, but these cases were always engaging our writing skills and other Spanish skills.
The biggest strength of this class is the small class size.
I found the topics/ units of the class to be extremely engaging. I also was really grateful that the instructor emphasized group work and working with new people.

The class did a good job at teaching us about the core topics. I also liked how we interacted with the movie we watched. It could be improved by having more of an emphasis on improving conversational skills. It would also help to have a little more clarity or advance notice on when assignments are due.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES, this is a very interesting Spanish class because it is less grammar filled and moreso application of Spanish.
Yes, this course is a good segue from L3 Spanish and does more than just teach you the language.
Yes! This course was fun, engaging and a great way to improve my Spanish.

I would definitely recommend this course to others students who are looking to improve their oral Spanish skills, while not solely practicing the language but learning about important cultural topics and movements taking place today.
Yes if they are trying to fulfill their language requirement
Yes, I enjoyed this class a lot because we implemented technical learning done in past classes and used it in the discussion-based course.
I would recommend this course to another student. I loved the professor and the way the course encouraged participation.
Absolutely
Yes! The coursework was really interesting and intellectually stimulating.
I would recommend this class to a student looking to take a language class. The workload is fair, and you get plenty of spanish practice while also learning about other things.
